title: Setting CPU Niceness for a Specific Application Using a Wrapper Script
context: User wanted to ensure specific applications always start with a defined CPU scheduling priority without altering global settings.
keyIdea: Use a simple wrapper script that launches the desired binary under a given niceness level, allowing per-application CPU priority tuning without root access or system-wide changes.
commands:
mkdir -p ~/.local/bin
nano ~/.local/bin/<appname>-wrapper
# Example wrapper content:
#!/bin/bash
exec nice -n -10 /usr/bin/<app-binary> "$@"

chmod +x ~/.local/bin/<appname>-wrapper
# Then configure launcher or runtime to use this wrapper
explanation: The wrapper uses `nice` to set a predefined CPU scheduling priority when launching an application. This provides fine-grained control for performance tuning or workload isolation without editing system limits or using root privileges.

reusabilityNotes.whenToReuse: Apply when you need to adjust CPU priority for a single app—games, compilers, or background tasks—without affecting the rest of the system.
reusabilityNotes.pitfalls: Avoid extremely low niceness values without root permissions; check that the wrapper is executable and properly referenced in your launcher or config.

uniquenessTag: Related to: "Set PolyMC Minecraft niceness to -10 via wrapper"
